Dialog:
Patient: I've been experiencing unexpected bleeding between my periods and I'm worried about what might be causing it.
TriageMD: I understand your concern about unexpected bleeding between periods. One possibility to consider is whether you could be pregnant. It might be a good idea to take a pregnancy test or consult with a healthcare provider for further evaluation.
Previous Protocol: Could you be pregnant?
Next Protocol: Could you be pregnant?

Dialog:
Patient: No, I don't think I could be more than 3 months pregnant. My last period was about a month ago, and the timing of the unprotected sex was more recent than that. I'll definitely take a pregnancy test soon to make sure, and then I'll reach out to my healthcare provider to discuss the results and any next steps.
TriageMD: It's good that you're planning to take a pregnancy test and consult your healthcare provider. In the meantime, do you have any severe abdominal pain?
Previous Protocol: Could you be more than 3 months pregnant?
Next Protocol: Do you have severe abdominal pain?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's important that you see a doctor immediately. The symptoms you're experiencing could be serious, and there is a possibility of cervical or uterine cancer. Please seek medical attention as soon as possible.
Previous Protocol: Do you have a heavy, watery vaginal discharge, or does the bleeding occur immediately after intercourse?
Next Protocol: See a doctor immediately. You may have cancer of the cervix or cancer of the uterus.

Dialog:
Patient: We've been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Could there be an issue with my fertility?
TriageMD: I understand that trying to conceive can be challenging. Have you noticed any unusual swelling of your testicles? This could be relevant to your fertility concerns.
Previous Protocol: Have you noticed any unusual swelling of your testicles?
Next Protocol: Have you noticed any unusual swelling of your testicles?

Dialog:
Patient: No, I haven't noticed any discharge, and I've never had an STD. My partner and I have both been healthy, and we haven't had any known issues in the past. We're just trying to figure out why it's taking longer than expected to conceive.
TriageMD: I understand how frustrating this can be. Have you had mumps after the age of 12? This could be relevant to your fertility concerns.
Previous Protocol: Do you have a discharge from your penis, or have you ever had a sexually transmitted disease (STD)?
Next Protocol: Did you have mumps after age 12?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes, we typically have intercourse less than once a week. Our schedules have been pretty busy, and sometimes it's difficult to find the time. We try to make the most of the opportunities we have, but I understand that frequency might play a role in our situation. We're open to any suggestions that might help us improve our chances of conceiving.
TriageMD: It's great that you're open to suggestions. Increasing the frequency of intercourse, especially around the time of ovulation, can improve your chances of conceiving. Consider tracking ovulation to help identify the best times. Finding ways to prioritize intimacy during this time can also be beneficial. If you have any further questions or concerns, feel free to reach out.
Previous Protocol: Do you have intercourse less than once a week?
Next Protocol: Your chances of conception will increase if you have intercourse more frequently, especially if you are able to have intercourse around the time of ovulation.

Dialog:
Patient: My daughter has been scratching her arms a lot, and I'm worried about what's causing it.
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that your daughter is experiencing this. Does she have any spots, blisters, or discolored areas on her body?
Previous Protocol: Does your child have spots, blisters, or discolored areas on any part of his or her body?
Next Protocol: Does your child have spots, blisters, or discolored areas on any part of his or her body?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes, I have noticed some tiny white spots in her hair that don't come off easily. I thought it might just be dandruff, but now I'm not so sure.
TriageMD: It sounds like those tiny white spots could be lice or nits, which can cause itching. It's important to check her scalp and hair closely. If you confirm that they are lice, you may want to consult a healthcare provider for treatment options.
Previous Protocol: Do you see tiny white spots clinging to your child's hair that cannot easily be rubbed off?
Next Protocol: Call your child's doctor. Your child may have lice.

Dialog:
Patient: Yes, I've noticed these tiny white spots in her hair that don't come off easily, and I'm starting to think they might be lice or nits. I've also noticed that she's been scratching her scalp quite a bit, which makes me concerned that it could be causing the itching on her arms as well. I'm planning to check her scalp more thoroughly and possibly consult a healthcare provider for advice on treatment options.
TriageMD: It sounds like your daughter may have lice, especially with the itching and the tiny white spots in her hair. I recommend calling your child's doctor for advice on treatment options. They can provide the best guidance for addressing this issue.
Previous Protocol: Call your child's doctor. Your child may have lice.
Next Protocol: Call your child's doctor. Your child may have lice.

Dialog:
Patient: I've noticed my urine looks cloudy and has a pinkish tint. Should I be worried about this change?
TriageMD: I understand your concern. Can you tell me if your urine is dark yellow or orange?
Previous Protocol: Is your urine dark yellow or orange?
Next Protocol: Is your urine dark yellow or orange?

Dialog:
Patient: I'm not really sure if I have a fever, but I don't feel particularly hot or anything. The weather's been kind of warm lately, and I have been doing some light exercise, but nothing too intense. I'm not sure if that could be affecting things.
TriageMD: It's understandable to feel uncertain. Just to clarify, is your temperature 100°F or higher?
Previous Protocol: s your temperature 100°F or higher, is the weather very hot, or have you been exercising?
Next Protocol: s your temperature 100°F or higher, is the weather very hot, or have you been exercising?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: Loss of fluid through vomiting or diarrhea can concentrate your urine, making it darker and possibly cloudier. It's important to drink more fluids, especially water or a rehydration solution or sports drink, to help with hydration. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please seek medical attention.
Previous Protocol: Have you been vomiting or have you had diarrhea?
Next Protocol: Loss of fluid through vomiting or diarrhea can concentrate the urine, making it darker. Drink more fluids, especially water or a rehydration solution or sports drink.

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing sharp pain when swallowing. Do you have a sore throat as well?
Previous Protocol: Do you have a sore throat?
Next Protocol: Do you have a sore throat?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: Do you sometimes experience pain in your chest, particularly when you squat, bend, or lie down?
Previous Protocol: Does food seem to stick high up in your chest after you swallow it?
Next Protocol: Do you sometimes experience pain in your chest, particularly when you squat, bend, or lie down?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health
Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: It sounds like you're experiencing some concerning symptoms. I recommend seeing your doctor for a proper evaluation, especially since swallowing is becoming difficult for you. Take care.
Previous Protocol: Do you swallow normally but feel a lump in your throat when you swallow or feel that the food will not go down?
Next Protocol: See your doctor if you are unable to make a decision from self-triage.

Dialog:
Patient: I've been coughing up bright red blood streaks, and I'm really worried about what could be causing this.
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing this. Can you please let me know if your temperature is 102°F or higher?
Previous Protocol: Is your temperature 102°F or higher?
Next Protocol: Is your temperature 102°F or higher?

Dialog:
Patient:  No.
TriageMD: Have you recently had surgery, been confined to bed, or sat for prolonged periods during a trip?
Previous Protocol: Are you coughing up mucus that is pink and frothy?
Next Protocol: Have you recently had surgery, been confined to bed, or sat for prolonged periods during a trip?

Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: It's important to see a doctor immediately if you're coughing up blood, even if it's just streaks. Please seek medical attention as soon as possible. Your health is a priority.
Previous Protocol: Have you had a cough for many weeks or months?
Next Protocol: See a doctor immediately if you are unable to make a decision from self-triage.

Next Protocol: Do you feel pain only when eating or just after eating?

Group: Eye,Ear, Node, Throat, and Oral Health

Next Protocol: Do you have repeated episodes of throbbing pain in the tooth?

Dialog:
Patient: I've been experiencing sudden twitching in my muscles and constant trembling. It's starting to worry me. What could be causing this?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing these symptoms. To better understand your situation, could you let me know if you are taking any medication?
Previous Protocol: Are you taking any medication?
Next Protocol: Are you taking any medication?

Dialog:
Patient: No, it's not just in one area. It seems to happen in different muscles, and I'm not really sure why.
TriageMD: I understand this can be concerning. Is the trembling or shaking limited to one part of your body, or is it more widespread?
Previous Protocol: Is the twitching limited to brief flickering movements of one small area of your body, such as an eyelid?
Next Protocol: Is the trembling or shaking limited to one part of your body?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's important that you see your doctor about these symptoms. They could be indicative of a nervous system disorder, such as Parkinson's disease, especially if you are over age 60. Please seek medical attention for a proper evaluation.
Previous Protocol: Is the trembling worse when you are not moving the affected part of the body?
Next Protocol: See your doctor. You could have a disorder of the nervous system called parkinson's disease, especially if you are over age 60.

Dialog:
Patient: I've noticed some swelling and pain in my testicles over the past few days. Should I be worried?
TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing swelling and pain in your testicles. Have you suddenly developed a painful swelling in one or both testicles?
Previous Protocol: Have you suddenly developed a painful swelling in one or both testicles?
Next Protocol: Have you suddenly developed a painful swelling in one or both testicles?

Dialog:
Patient: No, it's not really painless. It's more of a discomfort than anything else, but not exactly what I'd call painless.
TriageMD: Is only one of your testicles enlarged?
Previous Protocol: Do you have a painless swelling in your scrotum?
Next Protocol: Is only one of your testicles enlarged?

Dialog:
Patient: No, both of them seem to be affected. It's not like one is significantly larger than the other, but there's definitely some swelling and discomfort in both.
TriageMD: It's important to see a doctor about your symptoms, especially since you're experiencing swelling and discomfort in both testicles. They can provide a proper evaluation and determine the best course of action. Please consider making an appointment as soon as possible.
Previous Protocol: Is only one of your testicles enlarged?
Next Protocol: See your doctor if you are unable to make a decision from self-triage.

Dialog:
Patient: I've lost over 10 pounds in the past two months without changing my diet or exercise. Should I be worried?
TriageMD: It's understandable to be concerned about unexpected weight loss. Can you tell me if your appetite has remained the same as usual?
Previous Protocol: Is your appetite the same as usual?
Next Protocol: Is your appetite the same as usual?

Dialog:
Patient: No.
TriageMD: Have you been experiencing any recurring attacks of upper abdominal pain?
Previous Protocol: Have your bowel habits changed, or is there blood in your stools?
Next Protocol: Have you been having recurring attacks of upper abdominal pain?

Dialog:
Patient: Yes.
TriageMD: It's important that you see a doctor immediately. Your symptoms could indicate a serious chronic infection, such as tuberculosis or HIV, or a type of cancer like Hodgkin's disease. Please seek medical attention as soon as possible.
Previous Protocol: Do you have two or more of the following symptoms: sweating at night; recurring fever; unexplained fatigue; feeling generally ill; persistent cough; coughing up blood-tinged mucus?
Next Protocol: See a doctor immediately. You may have a serious chronic infection, such as tuberculosis or HIV. Or you could have a type of cancer such as hodgkin's disease.
